The 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution declared that "Neither slavery
nor involuntary servitude, except as a punishment for crime whereof the
party shall have been duly convicted, shall exist within the United
States, or any place subject to their jurisdiction." Formally abolishing
slavery in the United States, the 13th Amendment was passed by Congress on
January 31, 1865, and ratified by the states on December 6, 1865.
